Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether omission constitutes misrepresentation under subsection 40(1) requiring mens rea or materiality
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 40(1)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's belief that omission was immaterial not accepted
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment history, application form, supporting documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Omission of part-time employment at Adapana
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Requirement for full disclosure regardless of intent
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose all employment as required
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Materiality of the fact to immigration assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation includes unintentional omissions of material facts
Crimes.Application_Factor: Completeness of employment information

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material facts under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether omitted employment constitutes a material fact and if mens rea is required
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 40(1)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's subjective belief of immateriality rejected
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Non-disclosure of part-time job at Adapana
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of employment information to eligibility assessment
Crimes.Application_Error: Incomplete employment history disclosure
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Importance of fact to immigration process
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Material facts must be disclosed; no requirement for mens rea
Crimes.Application_Factor: Requirement for full employment details

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the inclusion of a fraudulent IELTS document constitutes material misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Document was designed to mislead
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of false documentation affecting immigration decision
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Potential to induce error in administration of the Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Inclusion of fraudulent document without applicant's knowledge
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Material misrepresentation under section 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Reliance on unauthorized immigration consultant
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Yes

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether submission of a fraudulent IELTS result constitutes material misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Document was designed to mislead
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of falsified language proficiency document
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Impact on integrity of immigration process
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to review application before submission
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Material misrepresentation under section 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Submission by unauthorized consultant
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Yes

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act violation
Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation and submission of counterfeit documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of IRPA regarding misrepresentation and inadmissibility
Crimes.Application_Facts: Counterfeit educational documents submitted for Ms. Bashir's daughter as part of immigration application
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Ms. Bashir, foreign national applying with family member
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: N/A - application refused prior to residency grant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Material misrepresentation through counterfeit documents, regardless of intent
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer provided procedural fairness via fairness letter and opportunity to respond
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ms. Bashir provided no evidence to refute knowledge of document falsity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of ignorance not supported by evidence, credibility undermined
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application refused due to inadmissibility under IRPA
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn of refusal and approval of application
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Misrepresentation found on record; procedural fairness upheld

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration application refusal based on fraud
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer’s refusal due to misrepresentation was reasonable and procedurally fair
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of ignorance not credible due to lack of supporting evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on misrepresentation leading to inadmissibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of counterfeit documents by family member affecting principal applicant
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of misrepresentation and failure to rebut concerns
Crimes.Application_Error: Inclusion of fraudulent educational credentials
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of document authenticity and materiality
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None — all evidence considered; applicant failed to provide countervailing evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness and procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Dependence on accuracy of supporting documents for family members
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal upheld; applicant remains inadmissible for two years
Crimes.Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) and Federal Court of Canada
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Confirmed counterfeit educational documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Withholding Material Facts Relating to Immigration Application
Legal_Issue: Was the Applicant's misrepresentation material to her admissibility under subsection 40(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 40(1)
Outcome: The application for judicial review was dismissed
Legal_Provision: subsection 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Misrepresentation induced an error in the administration of the Act
Application_Error: Admitting the son as a Canadian citizen based on false paternity claim
Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation or withholding material facts that could induce an error in the administration of the Act
Application_Factor: Claimed son was biological child of Canadian sponsor

Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 40(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant falsely claimed her son was the biological child of her Canadian sponsor
Legal_Standard_Applied: Misrepresentation that induces error in administration of the Act
Decision_Rationale: Misrepresentation was material and led to administrative error

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility due to misrepresentation and unauthorized work
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant’s failure to disclose a prior visa refusal and unauthorized employment constituted material misrepresentation under IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible for two years
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims were deemed not credible due to deliberate omissions
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, visa application history, signed application forms
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to disclose prior visa refusal and unauthorized full-time employment
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of omissions in influencing immigration decision-making
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Officer and Federal Court (on review)
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose prior visa refusal and false declaration of no unauthorized employment
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether the misrepresentation could induce an error in the administration of IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted; evidence of unauthorized employment was considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Material misrepresentation under IRPA subsection 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Accuracy and completeness of information provided in visa application
Crimes.Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), Federal Court of Canada
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No explicit document forgery, but false statements in application

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation by omission in visa application
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to disclose prior visa refusal and engaged in unauthorized full-time work from December 2010 to June 2012
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for temporary resident visa
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Withholding material facts regarding visa history and employment status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of administrative decision on misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Signed visa application, employment records, immigration history
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant’s claim of clerical error lacked supporting evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant not credible; signing application entails responsibility for accuracy
Crimes.Outcome: Sustained finding of inadmissibility due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Omissions were material and could induce error in visa assessment process
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer, Federal Court on judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Disclose Material Information under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over whether Ms. Abdallah's non-disclosure constituted misrepresentation under immigration law
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was Ms. Abdallah's failure to disclose the June 21 Call a misrepresentation under paragraph 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, IAD's decision set aside, appeal remanded for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Ms. Abdallah believed the Embassy's message might be an error or prank, but she had knowledge of the communication
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Communication from Embassy regarding sponsorship withdrawal, testimony about awareness and intent
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Withholding material information that could induce error in immigration administration
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Duty to disclose regardless of personal belief in accuracy of information
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative appeal followed by judicial review
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), later reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: IAD incorrectly applied exception for honest and reasonable belief
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether the omission could induce error in the administration of the Act
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: IAD initially failed to consider the duty to disclose despite uncertainty
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Materiality of withheld information and potential to mislead immigration authorities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Knowledge of sponsorship withdrawal attempt and decision not to disclose
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for re-determination due to legal and factual errors

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation through omission of material facts
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Abdallah was informed of sponsorship withdrawal and ceased communication with spouse, yet entered Canada without disclosure
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Sponsorship applicant seeking entry to Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Entry made without full disclosure affecting admissibility
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Withholding material information that could influence immigration decision
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Initial finding of inadmissibility overturned on appeal, then challenged via judicial review
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Interpretation of federal immigration law by administrative tribunal and court
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Embassy call records, border entry statements, testimony on awareness and intent
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation or explanation provided at time of entry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistent actions despite knowledge of potential inadmissibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD’s decision overturned; case remanded for re-evaluation
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal will be re-evaluated by another IAD member
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Allowance of sponsorship application and entry to Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the omission constitutes misrepresentation under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Withholding material facts constitutes misrepresentation regardless of actual sponsorship status
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Appeal Division, subject to Federal Court oversight

Crimes.Crime_Name: Indirect Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on dependant's connection to principal applicant's misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant is inadmissible under IRPA s. 40(1)(a) for indirectly misrepresenting material facts
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible; exclusion order upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly assessed for applicant due to reliance on principal applicant’s misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application documents, marital status records, family composition information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inclusion as dependant in principal applicant’s fraudulent immigration application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Principal applicant’s misrepresentation induced error in immigration process
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose principal applicant’s prior marriage and child
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – Board considered available evidence appropriately
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Interpretation of 'indirectly' under s. 40(1)(a) of IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Dependant status linked to principal applicant’s false representation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in immigration application regarding marital status and family

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation of material facts in immigration application
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant included as spouse of principal applicant who concealed existing marriage and child
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Dependant applicant in spousal sponsorship application
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: N/A – issue arose during landing/admissibility stage
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Withholding material facts (marital status and dependent child) that could induce error
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of IAD decision upholding exclusion orders
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of s. 40(1)(a) regarding indirect misrepresentation by dependants
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Immigration application forms, supporting documents, testimony or findings on marital status
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure about principal applicant’s prior family ties
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Principal applicant deemed not credible due to omission; dependant lacked knowledge
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion orders upheld; humanitarian and compassionate grounds dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn of exclusion order, stay of removal, humanitarian and compassionate consideration
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Cancellation of removal, permanent resident status
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Dependants are inadmissible when benefits derived from principal applicant’s misrepresentation
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Appeal Division, Federal Court of Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Modupe is inadmissible for misrepresentation under IRPA s. 40(1)(a) without knowledge of the false information
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Modupe's affidavit stating lack of knowledge was unchallenged and accepted
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of birth certificate listing Cladius as father despite non-biological relationship
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of knowledge regarding paternity
Crimes.Application_Error: Assuming intent to misrepresent without proof of knowledge
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Modupe’s credible explanation and lack of intent
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Knowingly misstating or withholding material facts
Crimes.Application_Factor: Reliance on official document without verifying biological parentage
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for redetermination by a different officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Incorrect birth certificate used, but not knowingly

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Modupe misrepresented material facts about Olakunle's paternity without knowledge
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Modupe’s belief in Cladius being the father deemed credible; disclosure of separation noted
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inclusion of Cladius as father on application based on official documentation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of intent to deceive; reliance on legal document and honest belief
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider applicant’s lack of knowledge and good faith
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Context of brief separation and reasonable belief in paternity
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Knowingly misrepresenting material facts under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of legally issued birth certificate reflecting presumed fatherhood
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by another officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Erroneous information submitted via birth certificate, no fraudulent intent found

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was Mr. Singh's failure to disclose his biological daughter a material misrepresentation under Section 40 of IRPA?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Outcome: Misrepresentation established, but humanitarian and compassionate assessment found unreasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Singh claimed ignorance of paternity, but court found duty of candour was breached
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Withholding material fact (existence of biological child) during immigration process
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Duty of candour and objective circumstances requiring inquiry into paternity
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), subject to Federal Court review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose a material fact that could induce error in immigration administration
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of the IAD's humanitarian and compassionate analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential mitigating circumstances related to knowledge of paternity
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Materiality of omission under IRPA Section 40
Crimes.Application_Factor: Objective foreseeability of paternity despite subjective denial
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion order upheld on misrepresentation grounds; case remanded for re-assessment of humanitarian and compassionate factors

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was Mr. Singh's failure to disclose his daughter a material fact under Section 40 of IRPA, and were humanitarian and compassionate considerations reasonably assessed?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Outcome: Misrepresentation established; humanitarian and compassionate assessment deemed unreasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of ignorance rejected due to duty of candour and circumstantial obligations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Non-disclosure of biological child during immigration application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of a duty to inquire into possible paternity based on surrounding circumstances
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Appeal Division, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission of material fact affecting immigration decision integrity
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of factual findings and legal interpretation
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Insufficient consideration of personal and family circumstances in H&C assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Material misrepresentation under IRPA Section 40
Crimes.Application_Factor: Objective basis for knowing or investigating paternity
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissal overturned; case remanded for rehearing by a different IAD panel

Legal_Issue: Whether refusal to perform military service constitutes grounds for refugee status or protection under IRPA
Credibility_Assessment: Ozunal failed to prove association with persecuted groups or illegitimate military actions
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, evidence on prison conditions, military service laws
Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on Convention refugee status and person in need of protection
Basis_of_Claim: Conscientious objection, fear of persecution for draft evasion
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Punishment deemed reasonable (up to 3 years), prison conditions acceptable, no link to Convention grounds
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Assessment_Standard: Whether punishment is disproportionate or inhumane, connection to Convention grounds
Legal_Standard: Persecution under international standards, risk to life or cruel treatment
Application_Factor: Nature of military service, motive for refusal, conditions upon return
Decision_Outcome: Not a Convention refugee, no need for protection

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer breached procedural fairness or made an unreasonable decision
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide adequate response; submitted documents lacked authenticity
Legal_Provision: Section related to misrepresentation in immigration applications
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to substantiate document authenticity after fairness letter
Application_Error: Misrepresentation of property ownership through suspicious documents
Application_Factor: Submission of supporting documents for financial standing
Decision_Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible for two years
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for merits, correctness for procedural fairness
Document_Fraud: Property certificates suspected and treated as inauthentic

Crimes.Crime_Name: Submitting inauthentic documents for an immigration application
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – authenticity requirements
Application_Facts: Applicant submitted property certificates that were deemed inauthentic
Procedural_Issue: Officer did not disclose underlying evidence of fraud but issued a fairness letter
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant failed to provide verifiable proof of ownership
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility undermined due to lack of verification
Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible for two years
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for decision merits
Decision_Rationale: Applicant was given opportunity to respond but failed to provide credible evidence

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and sought exemption from deportation based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Applicant not informed of concerns about marriage bona fides and denied opportunity to respond

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess risk of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96, Section 97
Governing_Law: IRPA, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution in China due to involvement with underground Christian church; non-leadership role; small group size; located in a liberal province
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to adequately address key evidence on doctrinal differences between state-sanctioned and underground churches
Evidence_Used: Testimony on religious practices, documentation on China's treatment of underground churches, location and size of religious group
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD ignored evidence regarding doctrinal differences between state and underground churches
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on RPD's interpretation of objective evidence
Decision_Outcome: RPD initially dismissed claim, finding no serious risk of persecution
Outcome: Judicial review granted; RPD decision overturned
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim with proper assessment of religious persecution risk
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA and international refugee law
Decision_Rationale: RPD erred by dismissing doctrinal differences and equating lack of past imprisonment with absence of persecution risk
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Legal_Issue: Was the decision to revoke Mr. Clue's Transportation Security Clearance (TSC) procedurally fair and supported by evidence?
Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Clue was uncooperative during investigations
Evidence_Type: Alleged placement of a loaded handgun on an aircraft
Legal_Provision: Section related to TSC under Aeronautics Act
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged involvement in placing a loaded handgun on an aircraft

Violation_Type: Potential unlawful interference with civil aviation
Application_Facts: Alleged involvement in loading a handgun onto an aircraft
Decision_Rationale: Reasonable belief of potential security threat

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and evidentiary support for TSC revocation

Crime_Name: Administrative Dispute over Band Council Elections
Dispute_Type: Election dispute between competing band customs for council leadership
Legal_Issue: Which band custom governs the election of the Nekaneet band council: the Referendum Band Custom or the Second Band Custom?
Evidence_Assessment: Referendum Band Custom approved by 83% of participating voters (113 out of 136); minor irregularities did not affect outcome; Second Band Custom passed by show of hands without clear consensus
Decision_Outcome: Referendum Band Custom is valid and governs elections; Applicants recognized as rightful Chief and Councillors
Burden_of_Proof: On Applicants to demonstrate validity of Referendum Band Custom and lack of broad consensus for Second Band Custom
Credibility_Factor: High voter participation in referendum (113/136) and significant portion of eligible voters (267 total) supports legitimacy
Legal_Rule: Under the Indian Act, band customs must reflect a broad consensus among band members
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness and correctness, as applicable to judicial review and writ of quo warranto
Grounds_for_Claim: Two conflicting elections held under different customs causing uncertainty over legitimate council
Outcome_on_Merits: In favor of Applicants; Respondents' claim to office declared invalid
Key_Evidence_Considered: Referendum results (113-23), voter turnout, procedural irregularities, method of adoption of Second Band Custom
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Act allowing judicial review and issuance of writs of quo warranto
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated, but implied defense of validity of Second Band Custom adopted by show of hands
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (referendum results), oral procedure (show of hands), procedural records
Remedy_Requested: Declarations of rightful office holders and writ of quo warranto
Outcome: Court granted declarations; Applicants declared legitimate band council
Legal_Provision: Section 74 of the Indian Act (band elections), Federal Courts Act sections on judicial review and prerogative writs

Legal_Provision_Violated: Statutory limits on visa officer decision-making authority
Governing_Law: Immigration Act, applicable statutory framework governing visa officers' powers
Application_Facts: Visa officer initially refused application on January 10, 1994; issued a new refusal letter on March 16, 1994, with new grounds after applicant's challenge
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged misrepresentation of qualifications and experience in the initial application
Procedural_Issue: Issuance of a second refusal decision without statutory authority to reconsider
Jurisdictional_Issue: Visa officer lacked jurisdiction to reconsider and issue a new refusal decision after the initial refusal
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of statutory basis for reinitiating decision-making process
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly addressed; focus was on procedural legality
Outcome: Judicial review application dismissed; applicant may seek extension to challenge original January 10, 1994, decision
Relief_Sought: Invalidation of the March 16, 1994, refusal decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of visa officer's decision-making powers
Standard_of_Review: Correctness, as it involves a question of jurisdiction and statutory authority
Decision_Rationale: Once a visa officer exercises statutory authority to refuse an application, they cannot issue a new refusal unless statute permits reconsideration. The officer had no such authority here.

Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate Grounds Application Rejection
Application_Facts: Lack of substantive evidence regarding hardship or unique circumstances; consideration of children's interests in Canada and Nigeria
Evidence_Used: Assessment of hardship, establishment, and risk factors
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of substantive evidence on hardship or unique circumstances
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the children as a factor in H&C assessment
Decision_Rationale: No compelling reasons to grant an exception; children's interests considered but not outweighing other factors

Legal_Issue: Whether applicants can prove irreparable harm to justify a stay of removal
Evidence_Assessment: Business loss and potential U.S. detention were unsubstantiated; no evidence of life-threatening harm upon return
Decision_Outcome: Motion denied, removal order to proceed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to meet burden of proving irreparable harm
Credibility_Factor: Claims discredited; no credible risk found by Refugee Division and PRRA officer
Legal_Rule: Irreparable harm must be proven, not speculative, and cannot rely solely on discredited claims
Standard_of_Review: Assessment based on prior tribunal decisions and Federal Court review
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk in returning to Turkey, potential harm in the U.S.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Findings of Refugee Division and PRRA officer, lack of evidence on business loss and detention risk
Legal_Framework: Immigration and refugee protection legislation, stay of removal procedures
Authority: Federal Court, Refugee Division, PRRA officer

Legal_Issue: Can the Court issue a nunc pro tunc order to avoid termination of an immigration application under s. 87.4(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Governing_Law: Section 87.4(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Application submitted before February 27, 2008; no decision made by March 29, 2012
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate jurisdictional error or reviewable error
Legal_Rule: Section 87.4(1) terminates applications for permanent resident visas in the federal skilled worker category if not decided by March 29, 2012
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on nature of legal issue
Grounds_for_Claim: Seeking reinstatement via nunc pro tunc order to overcome legislative termination
Outcome_on_Merits: No relief granted; Court lacks jurisdiction to override statutory termination
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of application submission; date of legislative cutoff; status of application processing
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act; principles of administrative law; court jurisdiction
Defendant_Response: Parliament’s intent under s. 87.4(1) is clear and binding; courts cannot extend jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Nunc pro tunc order to reinstate immigration application
Outcome: Application dismissed; no jurisdiction to countermand Parliament's intent
Legal_Provision: s. 87.4(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Respondent was physically present in Canada for only 406 days over four years; travel pattern indicated primary residence in Hong Kong; absences due to full-time employment abroad
Misrepresentation_Element: Implied — reliance on passive indicia such as tax returns and leases despite lack of substantial presence
Procedural_Issue: Respondent failed to appear for two videoconference hearings
Evidence_Used: Travel records, tax returns, lease agreements, employment information
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Passive indicia insufficient to establish residency; lack of credible evidence of actual residence in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Undermined — life centered in Hong Kong, minimal physical presence in Canada
Relief_Sought: Minister sought reversal of approval based on non-compliance with residency requirements
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo test for assessing residency under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Respondent failed to meet statutory physical presence requirement; Citizenship Judge erred in fact and law by relying on insufficient evidence
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via Citizenship Judge), reviewed by Federal Court
